coredata.dc:description: Surface structure of bimetallic catalysts plays a vital role in converting liquid hydrocarbon fuels to on-site H2 for fuel cell application via steam reforming process. Herein, Pt-outer (Pt-Ni/Al2O3), Pt-outer & inner (NiPt/Al2O3) and Pt-inner (Ni-Pt/Al2O3) catalysts prepared through sequential impregnation and co-impregnation method were employed in n-dodecane steam reforming. Performance results showed that the activity was as followed: Ni-Pt/Al2O3 > NiPt/Al2O3 > Pt-Ni/Al2O3. Characterization results from XRD, H2-TPR, XPS, STEM-EDX, in situ CO-DRIFT and EXAFS suggest that Ni-Pt/Al2O3 catalyst was more preferable to form Nix+ species and NiPt alloy compared with Pt-Ni/Al2O3 and NiPt/Al2O3 catalysts. C2H6-TPSR and H2O-TPSR experimental indicated that Ni-Pt/Al2O3 catalyst and Nix+ species mostly contributed to CC, CH bond and H2O activation. The superior activity of Ni-Pt/Al2O3 bimetallic catalyst in n-dodecane steam reforming linked with the synergistic effect between Ni-enriched surface, Nix+ species and NiPt alloy which facilitated CHx group formation, H2O activation and CHx group oxidation.

ce:abstract-sec.ce:simple-para: Surface structure of bimetallic catalysts plays a vital role in converting liquid hydrocarbon fuels to on-site H2 for fuel cell application via steam reforming process. Herein, Pt-outer (Pt-Ni/Al2O3), Pt-outer & inner (NiPt/Al2O3) and Pt-inner (Ni-Pt/Al2O3) catalysts prepared through sequential impregnation and co-impregnation method were employed in n-dodecane steam reforming. Performance results showed that the activity was as followed: Ni-Pt/Al2O3 > NiPt/Al2O3 > Pt-Ni/Al2O3. Characterization results from XRD, H2-TPR, XPS, STEM-EDX, in situ CO-DRIFT and EXAFS suggest that Ni-Pt/Al2O3 catalyst was more preferable to form Nix+ species and NiPt alloy compared with Pt-Ni/Al2O3 and NiPt/Al2O3 catalysts. C2H6-TPSR and H2O-TPSR experimental indicated that Ni-Pt/Al2O3 catalyst and Nix+ species mostly contributed to CC, CH bond and H2O activation. The superior activity of Ni-Pt/Al2O3 bimetallic catalyst in n-dodecane steam reforming linked with the synergistic effect between Ni-enriched surface, Nix+ species and NiPt alloy which facilitated CHx group formation, H2O activation and CHx group oxidation.

ce:section.ce:para: Liquid hydrocarbon fuels steam reforming is believed to be one of the most promising routes to produce on-site H2 production for fuel cell application [1]. Sorts of heterogeneous catalysts, such as Rh [2], Ru [3] and Ni [1], have been applied to this steam reforming process. Among these catalytic systems, Ni-based catalysts are expected to be a good candidate owing to high performance and low cost. However, deactivations derived from carbon deposition and sintering of Ni catalyst also limit its availability, especially in steam reforming of heavy hydrocarbons [4]. It has been demonstrated that noble doped Ni-based catalysts owing to electronic effect showed superior activities and excellent carbon resistance in reforming processes [5,6]. For that reason, one promising strategy of catalyst development for liquid hydrocarbon fuels steam reforming is to use noble modified Ni based catalysts. Among various noble modified Ni-based catalysts, we mainly focused on the Pt-doped Ni catalysts, in which the high selectivity towards hydrogen production of Pt is applied.

To the best acknowledge, several studies on NiPt bimetallic systems in steam reforming and dry reforming process have been reported and some encouraging results about this bimetallic catalysts also have been obtained [7–9]. However, current conclusions on NiPt bimetallic catalysts in reforming process are controversy. Chen et al. [10] reported that the performance of NiPt catalysts toward ethylene glycol aqueous phase reforming was superior to monometallic Pt catalysts, which was likely owing to Ni-terminated surface. A similar study has been conducted by Salciccioli et al. [11], which predicted that Ni-terminated bimetallic surface displayed higher performance by combining experimental results with microkinetic models. Chen et al. [12] also investigated the performance of NiPt catalysts for ethane or butane dry reforming through in-situ experimental and density functional theory (DFT) method, suggesting that the Pt-enriched surface structure would lower the activation energy of CC bond cleavage, thus promoting the performance of dry reforming. Similarly, the enhanced activity of methane drying reforming was attributed to the surface of PtNi catalysts with Pt dominated centers whose electron-withdrawing property got strengthened by Ni [13]. Liu and co-authors reported that Pt-enriched surface of PtNi (111) catalyst was favorable to the direct dissociation of CO2 to form CO and *O intermediates, in which the cleavage of C-O was one fundamental step, and the *O species facilitated the formation of *C2HyO intermediates for syngas production in dry reforming of ethane [14]. On above basis, the surface structure of NiPt catalysts plays a key role in reforming process.

At present, much attention has been focused on the methane dry reforming or oxygenated hydrocarbons aqueous-phase reforming over NiPt/Al2O3 bimetallic catalyst system. In contrast, few studies have been focused on liquid hydrocarbon fuels steam reforming on NiPt bimetallic system. As far as we know, liquid hydrocarbon fuels steam reforming reaction involves sequential cleavage of CC bond and reactions of C1 – fragments from the CC cleavage (in which C1 – fragments are converted to CO, CO2 by breaking CH bond and reacting with O species from H2O), which is similar with but not identical to the steam reforming of oxygenated molecules or methane. For example, in methane steam reforming, there is no CC bond cleavage reaction except for CH bond cleavage (several researches have indicated that the cleavage of CH bond is the first and rate-determining step in methane steam reforming [15,16]). Nevertheless, it should be noted that CH bond cleavage is different from CC bond cleavage. Therefore, it is a valuable study of the effect of surface structure of NiPt catalyst on liquid hydrocarbon fuels steam reforming.

In present work, we investigated the effect of surface structure of NiPt catalytic catalyst system on n-dodecane (a sort of surrogate liquid hydrocarbon fuels) steam reforming. The variable surface structure of NiPt bimetallic catalysts by tailing Pt locations were synthesized using sequential impregnation and co-impregnation method. Catalysts properties were investigated through X-ray diffraction (XRD), H2 temperature-programmed reduction (H2-TPR), X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS), In situ Diffuse Reflectance Infrared Fourier Transform Spectroscopy (DRIFT), extended X-ray adsorption fine structure analysis (EXAFS), Scanning transmission electron microscopy with energy dispersive X-ray (STEM-EDX), Temperature programmed surface reaction (TPSR), Scanning electron microscopy (SEM), thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) and Raman spectra. On this basis, the relationship between surface structure and catalytic performance of n-dodecane steam reforming is discussed.

The alumina support (Al2O3) was synthesized according to our previous studies [1,17]. As to the metal precursor, such as Ni(NO3)2·6H2O and H2PtCl6·6H2O, were from Sigma-Aldrich Chemical Inc. For the co-impregnation method, catalyst was synthesized via wet impregnation method using a mixed solution containing both nickel and platinum metal precursor. All impregnated samples were dried at 110 °C overnight and calcined at 500 °C for 3 h, which was denoted as NiPt/Al2O3. In the sequential impregnation method, the first metal introduction is Ni component using Ni(NO3)2 aqueous solution, and then Pt component was loaded by impregnating H2PtCl6 solution. All impregnated samples were dried overnight at 110 °C after each impregnation step. After each drying step, samples were calcined at 500 °C and 300 °C, respectively, denoted as Pt-Ni/Al2O3. For Ni-Pt/Al2O3 catalyst, catalyst was prepared by reversing metal component introduction order in which Pt component was firstly loaded (dried sample calcined at 300 °C for 3 h), and after Ni component was introduced (dried sample calcined at 500 °C for 3 h).

Inductively coupled plasma mass spectroscopy (ICP-MS) (by NexION) was employed to determine the content of Pt and Ni metal. In this measurement, a mixed solution of HNO3/HCl/HF was used to digest catalysts power.

N2 adsorption–desorption isotherms were recorded at −196 °C (Micomeritics ASAP 2420) to obtain physical properties (surface areas, pore volumes and pore size). Sample degassing before this test was at 250 °C for 3 h.

CO-pulse chemisorption was conducted to obtain metal dispersion information on a chemisorption analyzer (Micromeritics AutoChem 2910). Testing catalysts ( ~ 100 mg) were reduced at 600 °C for 2 h under 10% H2/Ar gas, and subsequently reduced catalysts were cooled to 50 °C. CO gas was pulsed injection until CO remained peak became stable. Information about dispersion was calculated based on the pulse CO chemisorption. H2-TPR was conducted on the same apparatus as the CO chemisorption. The sample was reduced in a 10% H2/Ar gas with a rate of 5 °C/min to 800 °C.

Temperature-programmed surface reaction (TPSR) was conducted to investigate the ability of various catalysts for CC, CH bonds and H2O activation. Ethane (C2H6) was chosen as model molecule. C2H6-TPSR was conducted on the Micromeritics AutoChem 2910. 80 mg catalyst sample was treated in 10%H2/Ar gas at 600 °C for 2 h and then cooled to 50 °C, 20% C2H6/N2 gas or was introduced to sample for 30 min, and then system temperature was increased to 800 °C with a rate of 10 °C/min. Products were detected by mass spectrometry (MS). H2O-TPSR was conducted for Ni-Pt/Al2O3 catalyst, in which catalyst was treated in 10% H2/Ar gas at 500 °C, 550 °C and 600 °C respectively for 2 h. Other steps were the same as C2H6-TPSR test.

XRD was performed on a Rigaku C/max-2500 with 2θ values between 15° and 85° with a Cu Kα radiation (λ = 1.5406 Å). The diffraction peak of Ni (200) plane was employed to estimate Ni crystalline based on the Scherrer’s equation.

STEM-EDX was performed on a JEM-2100F (JEOL) at 200 kV. Before this analysis, samples were dispersed in ethanol, and subsequently deposited on Cu grid coated with a perforated carbon film. SEM was measured on an Apero S LoVac to examine the surface of spent catalysts.
XPS data were collected on a PHI 5000 Versaprobe. Samples were reduced at 600 °C in H2 gas (30 ml/min) for 2 h before the XPS measurement.

In-situ DRIFT technique was employed to investigate the CO adsorption on the surface of NiPt bimetallic system on a Bruker 70 equipped with Praying Mantis DRIFT accessory and three window DRIFT cells from Harrick Scientific. Catalysts were in-situ reduced in H2 gas (30 ml/min) at 600 °C for 2 h before the background spectrum collection at room temperature (50 °C). For CO adsorption experiments, samples were then exposed to CO for 30 min, and all DRIFTS profiles were recorded with 64 scans at a resolution of 4 cm−1.

EXAFS spectra were collected at 1W1B beam line in Beijing Synchrotron Radiation Facility (BSRF). All samples were reduced with a 30 ml/min flowing H2 gas at 600 °C for 2 h. After then, energies of reduced samples were selected using a Si (111) double crystal monochromator in the fluorescent mode. As to the fitting process, the data of EXAFS was treated using Athena, and shell fitting was performed using Artemis. Pt foil and Ni foil were employed as references of the fitting process.
TGA technique was to quantitate carbon deposition on spent catalyst using a TA-Q500. Spent catalysts (~ 10 mg) were heated in air (40 ml/min) to 800 °C (10 °C/min).
Raman spectroscopy was used to analyze types of carbon deposition using a DXR Microscope system. The spectra were excited by a 532 nm laser at a range of 1000–2000 cm−1.

N-dodecane steam reforming test was conducted at atmospheric pressure using a fixed reactor (4 mm ID) at atmospheric pressure. Typically, catalysts around 20–30 mesh were loaded on the above reactor and in-situ reduced at 600 °C for 2 h in H2 gas (30 ml/min). After a reduction process, inert N2 gas (60 ml/min) was switched to the reactor and temperature was heated to reaction temperature with a ramping rate of 5 °C/min. The reactants including n-dodecane and water (determined from steam to water (S/C) ratio) were pumped, and then above reactants with N2 gas (30 ml/min) were vaporized (the evaporator temperature at 300 °C) and sent to catalyst bed reactor. The outlet phase was separated through the cold trap, in which gas products were on-line analyzed via a gas chromatography (GC, Agilent Micro 490 together with TCD detectors and columns (PPU, 5 Å molecular sieve, and alumina)). N-dodecane conversion and gas products formation rate were employed to quantify catalytic performance, which is also based on our previous report [1]. For apparent activation energy measurement, less catalyst (~ 100 mg) was diluted with quartz silica to ensure the lower conversion (< 20%) in investigated temperature range (550–650 °C).

Fig. 1 shows the diffraction patterns of reduced bimetallic catalysts. It can be seen that all samples contain Al2O3 phase (JCPDS No. 79-1558) at 2
θ
=
37.7°, 45.8°, and 66.8°. Moreover, diffraction peaks at 44.3°and 51.7°, which are indexed to the planes (111) and (200) of Ni phase (JCPDS No. 04-0850), respectively, are presented in all samples. Specifically, the Ni (200) plane is employed to estimate the crystal size (see Table 1). For these bimetallic catalysts, a new peak at 39° is detected for NiPt/Al2O3 and Pt-Ni/Al2O3 catalyst, attributing to Pt (111) plane (JCPDS No. 04-0802). On the other hand, no peak appears at 2
θ ≈ 39 °
corresponding to Pt phase in Ni-Pt/Al2O3 catalyst, inferring small Pt crystal size or the form of NiPt alloy. In addition, the peak related to Ni (200) shows a lower degree shift for Ni-Pt/Al2O3 and NiPt/Al2O3 catalyst (see Fig. 1B). Based on the Vegard's law, the shift of metal peaks in bimetallic catalysts may suggest the formation of some bulk alloy [6]. Studies about Ni-Pt alloy by the replacement of Ni atoms through Pt atoms have been reported in literature [18,19]. Therefore, the above shift could be due to the alloying of NiPt. Furthermore, it’s worth noting that the Ni crystal size of Ni-Pt/Al2O3 catalyst has the smallest size of any catalyst studied (see Table 1), which could be due to a partial re-dispersion of Ni species on Pt/Al2O3 support during the second impregnation, which is similar with previous report [20].

H2-TPR results displayed in Fig. 2 revealed reduction behavior of these NiPt catalysts. In Fig. 2A, a peak observed around 150–250 °C is related to PtOx species reduction for NiPt/Al2O3 and Pt-Ni/Al2O3 catalyst based on literature reports [21]. Remarkably, no peak around 150–250 °C is found for Ni-Pt/Al2O3, speculating the existence of Ni-Pt alloy for Pt species, in agreement with XRD results. Furthermore, there is a hydrogen consumption peak around 300–800 °C, suggesting some variant of nickel oxides species reduction. To determine those various types nickel oxides, the TPR profiles were fit via Gaussian-type functions (see Fig. 2B–D), in which different types of catalyst was marked with different color. It is found that three kinds of NiO species are presented in these catalysts. Specially, one reduction temperature is under 500 °C (blue line in Fig. 2B–D), which is ascribed to free NiO species reduction. Besides, another reduction peak in temperature region (500–700 °C) (pink line in Fig. 2B–D) is attributed to the reduction of non-stoichiometric nickel aluminates species (several literatures regarded this kinds of species as defect NixAlyOz species or surface nickel aluminates [22,23], ascribed to moderate metal-support interaction) [24,25]. The reduction temperature above 700 °C (olive line in Fig. 2B–D) is ascribed to nickel aluminate (NiAl2O4) species reduction based on previous investigation [26]. Since there is the NiAl2O4 phase, a 100% degree of reduction could not be achieved. It is worth mentioning that the highest reduction degree is 80% for Ni-Pt/Al2O3 in studied NiPt catalysts (see Table 1). Furthermore, it is remarkable that the percentages of middle temperature peak area (moderate metal-support interaction NiO species) of Ni-Pt/Al2O3 is higher than the data of NiPt/Al2O3 and Pt-Ni/Al2O3 (see Table 2), which suggests, probably, the higher co-incorporation between two metals (Ni and Pt) and a strong Ni-O-Al interaction caused by Pt locations. Chen and co-worker reported that Pt enriched surface with a Ni sub-layer structure easily generated NiAl2O4 phase, whereas the Ni-rich surface with a Pt sub-layer structure tend to form NiO species with moderate metal-support interaction [27]. Therefore, our results (see Table 2) also implied the formation Pt-outer, Pt-outer & inter, and Pt-inner structure for Pt-Ni/Al2O3, NiPt/Al2O3, and Ni-Pt/Al2O3 catalyst, respectively.

XPS technique is employed to reveal surface composition and surface species environment of these NiPt catalytic systems, the results of which are listed in Table 3. The detailed fitting results of Ni2p3/2, Pt4d5/2 XPS spectra are displayed in Fig. 3. As to Ni2p3/2 spectra, the deconvolution of Ni2p3/2 spectra displays peaks centered at BE ≈ 856.0 eV, 855.0 eV as well as 852.0 eV, which are characteristic of NiAl2O4, Nix+ and Ni0 species deriving from the reduction of NiAl2O4 species, defect NixAlyOz species or surface NiAl2O4 as well as NiO species based on the theoretical values for these species reported from literature [28–31], suggesting surface Ni species in variant environments. With regard to the existence of NiAl2O4 species, the Ni species of these bimetallic catalysts are not fully reduced. It is worth mentioning that Ni-Pt/Al2O3 catalyst presents the lowest percentage of NiAl2O4 species accompanied with the highest percentage of Nix+ species, which is consistent with results of H2-TPR (see Table 2). On the other hand, a fitted peak centered at 314.0 eV registered to Pt0 is presented in all catalysts, indicating the Pt species is fully reduced. Remarkably, a weak peak attributed to Pt4d5/2 is found for Ni-Pt/Al2O3 catalyst based on the XPS data, inferring that the concentration of Pt on the surface is relative low. In order to further explore the Pt locations in NiPt bimetallic catalysts, the composition of surface and bulk for these NiPt bimetallic catalysts was investigated by XPS and ICP-MS, which is listed in Table 1. In particular, the molar ratio is 0.05 (bulk composition from ICP-MS) in comparison to 0 (surface composition derived from XPS) for that of Ni-Pt/Al2O3 catalyst. For Pt-Ni/Al2O3 catalyst, the molar ratios (bulk composition v.s. surface composition) are 0.06 and 0.25, respectively. Hence, from the composition comparison, it suggested that Ni-Pt/Al2O3 catalyst exhibited Ni surface enrichment, whereas surface was enriched with Pt for Pt-Ni/Al2O3 catalyst, in agreement with target Pt-outer and Pt-inner structures.

To further explore the surface difference of these NiPt bimetallic systems, in situ DRIFT spectra based on a CO adsorption test were performed, as described in Fig. 4. In Fig. 4, the Ni/Al2O3 and Pt/Al2O3 prepared by impregnation method are employed as references. As far as Ni/Al2O3 catalyst is concerned, the band around 2050 cm−1 is ascribed to Ni0 linear adsorption based on a previous report [32]. In addition, the IR band at 2175 cm−1 is ascribed to CO interacting with Ni2+ ions, such as NiO particles or NiAl2O4 [13,32]. With regard to Pt/Al2O3 catalyst, the 2082 cm−1 IR band is assigned as CO adsorption on Pt atoms, which is in line with the investigation from Li and co-workers [33,34]. It should be noted that the band at 2117 cm−1 is found for all samples, which is tentatively attributed to the M (O)-CO (M representing Ni or Pt), in accordance with previous studies by Li group [35]. Moreover, the IR band at 2175 cm−1 ascribed to NiAl2O4 as mentioned above is observed for all bimetallic samples. Therefore, we inferred some types of nickel oxidation species are still on the surface, which is consistent with our above results (see Table 1, reduction degree). Notably, a peak centered near 2055 cm−1 is present for all reduced bimetallic samples, which is higher than the peak (~ 2050 cm−1) assigned to CO linear adsorption on Ni0 for Ni/Al2O3. This suggests the existence of Pt-Ni alloy, in agreement with previous studies [13]. Interestingly, the difference of these reduced bimetallic samples is the peak intensity at 2082 cm−1. Specifically, the intensity ratio of peak (I2082/I2055, representing Pt/Ni atoms on the surface) is as follows: Pt-Ni/Al2O3 (1.1) > NiPt/Al2O3 (0.6) ~ Ni-Pt/Al2O3 (0.5), indicating the decrease of Pt atoms on the surface. Furthermore, this ratio of Pt-Ni/Al2O3 is higher than 1.0, suggesting the surface with Pt enrichment for this catalyst. In contrast, the characterization results for Ni-Pt/Al2O3 indicated a Ni-enriched surface on the catalyst. Judging from the CO-DRIFT results, the difference in surface properties is due to Pt locations, which may lead to the difference in performance.

STEM (dark field) images of Ni-Pt/Al2O3 catalyst are shown in Fig. 5. Similar images of Pt-Ni/Al2O3 and NiPt/Al2O3 are described in SI (see Fig. S1). The STEM results show the metal nanoparticle (bright spots in STEM) on the alumina, in which the mean particle size is about 5–6 nm based on around 100 nanoparticles measurement (see Fig. 5C). Three random nanoparticles are chosen (red color dash circle in Fig. 5A) and done the EDX spectrum test (see Fig. 5B and D). The element compositional profile (line analysis) shown in Fig. 5D evidences that Pt atoms are enriched in the inner layers. Additionally, there are certain of overlaps between Ni element (Olive) with Pt (pink), inferring the formation of NiPt alloy, which is similar to our previous study [36] and Zhang’s observation [19].

Fig. 6 exhibits the Pt L3 – edge EXAFS spectra of these reduced NiPt system, and corresponding fitting results are listed in Table 4. Obviously, all spectra differ from the spectrum of Pt foil (see the dash line in Fig. 6), probably evidencing the formation of PtNi bond. Corresponding, the fitting information of PtNi bond also provides evidence that the existence of NiPt alloy. Literature proposed that average coordination number based on EXAFS characterization was rely on metal nanoparticle’s size and shape [35,37]. In general, the smaller size of metal nanoparticle size is, the lower coordination number (CN) is [38]. In Table 4, the lowest CN (Pt-Pt) is that of Ni-Pt/Al2O3 catalyst, indicating it has the smallest Pt particle size, which is in agreement with XRD results showing no peak attributed to Pt (see Fig. 1). Furthermore, the increase of CN (Pt-Ni) and decline in CN (Pt-Pt) rank as following: Ni-Pt/Al2O3 > NiPt/Al2O3 > Pt-Ni/Al2O3. Li and his co-authors reported that Ni atoms migrated into the outer surface, leading to a raise in CN (Pt-Ni) and a decline in CN (Pt-Pt) [35]. Therefore, the above observation suggests that the concentration of Ni in the surface of Ni-Pt/Al2O3 is the richest for these bimetallic catalysts (see Table 4), which is in line with the CO-DRIFT results. Furthermore, the proportion of CN (Pt-Ni) in total CN (CN (Pt-Ni) + CN (Pt-Pt)) of Ni-Pt/Al2O (61% for Pt-Ni/Al2O3, 73% for NiPt/Al2O3, and 86% for Ni-Pt/Al2O3) is the highest in these studied catalysts, suggesting that the alloy degree of this catalyst is the highest.

ce:section.ce:section-title: N-dodecane steam reforming over variant surface NiPt/Al2O3 catalysts
ce:section.ce:para: A comparison of different NiPt catalysts performs – with regard to n-dodecane conversion and products (including H2, CO, CO2) formation rate is displayed in Fig. 7. It can be observed that the performance (in terms of conversion and formation rate) is followed the trend of Pt-Ni/Al2O3 < NiPt/Al2O3 < Ni-Pt/Al2O3 under studied reaction conditions. Therefore, it could be inferred that performance differences are closely associated with structural differences. Strikingly, Ni-Pt/Al2O3 catalyst is more favorable to n-dodecane steam reforming reaction under studied conditions.

Except from the enhanced activity, all catalysts display deactivation presented in Fig. 7. Specifically, the n-dodecane conversion reduces to 54%, 24%, and 10% from 92%, 82%, and 24% for Ni-Pt/Al2O3, NiPt/Al2O3, and Pt-Ni/Al2O3 catalyst, respectively over 12 h. Previous studies believed that coking is caused by Boundouard reaction, reverse gasification and hydrocarbons decomposition in steam reforming process [48]. Reverse gasification and Boundouard reactions are favored in low temperatures regions [49]. Thus, the deactivation of these studied catalysts is likely to be related to coking. Investigation from Hayashi et al. concluded that coking on Ni/Al2O3 catalyst prepared by microemulsion method during the steam reforming methane were more gasified owing to the existence of Niδ+ in the catalysts [50]. Enger’s group reported that the reduction species from of non-stoichiometric nickel aluminates species like NixAlyOz species, may display higher coking resistance due to a higher oxygen surface mobility [23]. Simultaneously, the carbon deposition from CHx group was inhibited due to the enhanced CHx group oxidation due to the effect of NiPt alloy [35]. Thus, we infer that lower deactivation degree of Ni-Pt/Al2O3 system is mainly related with high alloy degree (see XRD, in situ CO DRIFT, EXAFS).

Apparent activation energy (Ea), derived from the Arrhenius plots (ln r versus reciprocal temperature (1/T)), of n-dodecane steam reforming over Ni-Pt/Al2O3, NiPt/Al2O3, and Pt-Ni/Al2O3 catalysts were studied in the kinetically controlled regime. Specifically, the Ea value of Ni-Pt/Al2O3 catalyst (Ea = 30.2 ± 2.1 kJ mol−1) is smaller than these values of NiPt/Al2O3 (Ea = 51.5 ± 2.2 kJ mol−1) and Pt-Ni/Al2O3 catalyst (Ea = 73.3 ± 1.9 kJ mol−1) (see Fig. 8). The variance in Ea infers that Ni-Pt/Al2O3 catalyst is more favorable, matching up with above studies results.

ce:section.ce:section-title: Investigation on catalytic ability of activating CC and CH bonds
ce:section.ce:para: C2H6-TPSR was conducted to explore variant surface NiPt catalysts ability for CC and CH bonds activation, in which H2 concentration is plotted in Fig. 9. In C2H6/N2 atmospheres under the same loading, the accumulation of H2 formation is followed the trend of Pt-Ni/Al2O3 < NiPt/Al2O3 < Ni-Pt/Al2O3, as the same following trend of catalytic performance, indicating that Ni-Pt/Al2O3 catalyst is favorable for the CC and CH bonds activation.

ce:section.ce:section-title: Investigation on Ni-Pt/Al2O3 catalyst ability for activating H2O
ce:section.ce:para: H2O-TPSR was conducted to explore Ni-Pt/Al2O3 catalyst ability for H2O molecule activation, in which catalysts were reduced in 10% H2/Ar gas at 500 °C, 550 °C and 600 °C respectively for 2 h to obtain different concentrations of Nix+ species based on the H2-TPR results (in which Ni0 species could be fully reduced see Fig. 2D). In Fig. 10, the accumulation of H2 formation is followed the trend of Ni-Pt/Al2O3 (500 °C) < Ni-Pt/Al2O3 (550 °C) < Ni-Pt/Al2O3 (600 °C), indicating that more Nix+ species facilitate H2O activation.

To elucidate performance – structure relationship of the above NiPt bimetallics in n-dodecane steam reforming, several reactions involved according to mechanisms suggested by Rostrup-Nielsen for methane steam reforming and higher aliphatic hydrocarbons steam reforming are discussed. Specifically, the first step included the formation of CHx group (Eqs. (1) and (2)) and oxygen-containing species (O or OH) (Eq. (3)) through the scission of CH, CC and OH bond. The second step is the oxidation of CHx group with the oxygen-containing species to yield CO and H2 (Eq. (4)). Meanwhile, some parallel reactions also occur during steam reforming process, such as water-gas shift reactions (WGS, Eq. (5)).

As for the formation of CHx group by the scission of CH and CC bond, investigations showed that this catalytic activity depends on the metal sites [39]. Based on the above characterization results (see Table 1), it is clear that the Ni-Pt/Al2O3 catalyst system exposed more active sites, which means that this catalyst could provide more actives sites for the formation of CHx group. In addition, García-Diégues et al. [40] observed that adding Pt promoted the formation NiO species with moderate metal-support interaction and facilitated its reduction to Ni0 during catalyst activation. According to the H2-TPR results, larger proportion of NiO species with moderate metal-support interaction was found on Ni-Pt/Al2O3 catalyst, inferring more Ni species produced from this NiO species reduction on the surface of Ni-Pt/Al2O3 catalyst, in accordance with dispersion results (see Table 2). On the other hand, Sinfelt’s group reported that the CC bond cleavage relative rate over Ni metal is higher than Pt metal, which could achieve comparable performance as Rh and Ru metal [41]. Gong and co-workers proposed that the higher C3H6 selectivity was observed on Pt-skin catalysts with 3d transition metal (such as Ni and Co) atoms in subsurface regions, whereas the selectivity of propane dehydrogenation decreased when the catalyst surface has both Pt and 3d transition metal exposed, which is due to the C-C cracking on exposed Co and Ni sites [42]. From the characterization of in situ CO-DRIFT results (see Fig. 3), Ni-Pt/Al2O3 catalyst owned Ni-enriched surface, while the surface of Pt-Ni/Al2O3 is enriched with Pt atom. Therefore, we infer that the Ni-Pt/Al2O3 is favorable for the formation of CHx group through the cleavage of CC bond reaction, since there are more Ni active sites on the surface. In comparison, the Pt-Ni/Al2O3 catalyst is preferential to the dehydrogenation reaction due to the Pt-enriched surface. For the CH cleavage, investigation from McEwen et al. suggested that metallic Ni atoms with positive charge facilitate the initial CH bond scission of methane [43]. In addition, Tiwari et al. predicted that the Pt-Ni catalysts with subsurface alloy structure display an enhanced activity in CH dissociation [44]. For comparison (see XPS data in Table 3 and EXAFS data in Table 4), Ni-Pt/Al2O3 catalyst owned more percentage of Nix+ species and NiPt alloy, thus leading to more advantages over CH cleavage. Furthermore, in combination with C2H6-TPSR result, Ni-Pt/Al2O3 catalysts indeed exhibited better performance toward CC and CH bonds activation. In summary, the Ni-Pt/Al2O3 catalysts is more favorable for the formation of CHx group considering the aspects like Ni-enriched surface, NiPt alloy and Nix+ species.

Apart from the formation of CHx group, H2O conversion including the formation and availability of O/OH species also plays an import role in steam reforming process. Fig. 7C and D displays the formation rate of CO and CO2 over Ni-Pt/Al2O3 is higher than that over other two catalysts, suggesting oxygen-containing species (O/OH) conversion over Ni-Pt/Al2O3 is higher than others (reactions through Eqs. (3) and (4)). In terms of H2O dissociation (oxygen-containing species formation), Bao et al. [45] provided experimental and DFT calculations investigation and suggested that the activity of H2O dissociation was enhanced due to the increased Lewis acidity of Ni sites for the Ni-O pairs at the NiOx-Ni interface. In general, based on the Lewis acid-base theory, the Nix+ species is general deemed as the Lewis acid for the NiOx metal-oxide system. In fact, it is found that the proportion of Nix+ species is higher on Ni-Pt/Al2O3 catalysts than that on other catalysts (see H2-TPR and XPS results). Based on the above analysis, we infer that the Nix+ sites probably facilitate the H2O conversion. From the H2O-TPSR, more Nix+ species indeed exhibited higher H2O conversion. Similar phenomena from Lucas concluded that Ni-Al2O3 interface sites which is different from the Ni0 sites due to the electronic effect act as a reservoir of reactive oxygen-containing species for WGS [46].

For the availability of O/OH species, the process generally includes the CHx oxidation (Eq. (3)) and WGS reaction (Eq. (4)). Zhang et al. [15] claimed that the alloying of PtNi (111) is in favor of CHx group adsorption. In addition, research from Li et al. indicated that Ni/Pt bimetallic system with a Ni/Pt alloy @ Ni (shell @ core) structure facilitated the oxidation of CH [35]. Moreover, it has been well established that adsorption of adsorbates, such as H2 and CO, on surface is weakened due to the NiPt alloy in NiPt bimetallic systems [47,48]. In combination with the above characterization results (see XRD, in situ CO DRIFT, EXAFS), a higher proportion of NiPt alloy are formed over Ni-Pt/Al2O3, which is as another explanation for the highest formation rate for the CO and CO2 products.

In combination with experimental, characterization results and above discussion, it is inferred that the highly performance of Ni-Pt/Al2O3 catalyst is attributed to the synergistic effect of Ni-enriched surface, Nix+ species and NiPt alloy, in which these species facilitate the CHx group formation, H2O dissociation and CHx group oxidation (see Fig. 11).

Since the above results indicated the superior performance of Ni-Pt/Al2O3 system, the following studies mainly focus on Ni-Pt/Al2O3 catalyst. Temperature plays a vital role in n-dodecane steam reforming process based on the strongly endothermic character [49,50]. Fig. 12 shows effects of temperature on the activity of Ni-Pt/Al2O3 catalyst in n-dodecane steam reforming process. It’s observed that increasing temperature indeed led to high conversion, which is in agreement with the endothermic reaction character as previous other reports [51]. Notably, the conversion is near 100% with around 2% deactivation degree over 700 °C during 12 h. Moreover, the deactivation degree increases to around 10% with a further increase of temperature (750 °C), which may be due the sintering both from the nanoparticle (crystal size increased to 10.6 nm after the reaction) and support (see Table S1).

Based on above studies, the reaction at 700 °C showed superior activity and stability at all the investigated temperatures during n-dodecane steam reforming process. Therefore, 700 °C is selected as reaction temperature for the following studies. In this process, steam is also a vital factor, considering that steam could prevent coking formation, but also requires more energy. Fig. 13 shows effect of S/C ratio on the activity of n-dodecane steam reforming over Ni-Pt/Al2O3 catalyst. In Fig. 13, the conversion of n-dodecane was almost total at studied S/C ratio, indicating that the S/C ratio has no obvious effect on the conversion of n-dodecane in steam reforming process under investigated conditions. Meanwhile, S/C ratio affects products distribution. Specifically, the initial conversion was around 99% with no evident deactivation (98% initial conversion decreases to 96% final conversion at S/C = 2, no obvious deactivation for others) for studied S/C ratios. In addition, the CO2/CO ratio shows a slight increase with the increase of S/C ratio, due to the WGS reaction.

The amount of carbon deposition on spent Ni-Pt/Al2O3, NiPt/Al2O3 and Pt-Ni/Al2O3 catalysts are measured by TGA technique, as depicted in Fig. 14. It is observed that the order of total carbon deposition is as follows: Pt-Ni/Al2O3 > NiPt/Al2O3 > Ni-Pt/Al2O3, which is in accordance with above catalytic results (see Fig. 7). In the DTG profiles (see Fig. 14B), a peak attributed to oxidation of carbon around 400–800 °C is observed for these catalysts. Investigations showed that amorphous carbon could be oxidized under 500 °C, and filamentous carbon oxidation occurs at 500–750 °C temperature range, while graphitic carbon is anticipated to be oxidized above 750 °C [52]. In Fig. 14B, only one peak attributed to filamentous carbon is found for Ni-Pt/Al2O3 catalyst. For NiPt/Al2O3 and Pt-Ni/Al2O3 catalyst, two peaks are observed, which are attributed to filamentous carbon, and graphitic carbon, respectively. Notably, the peak attributed to oxidization graphic carbon peak of NiPt/Al2O3 shifted to lower temperature. The precursors of filamentous coke formation through decomposition reaction and Boundouard reaction is well established in the literature [53–55], and some researchers proposed that this kind of filamentous coking had a much lower impact on deactivation [53]. Huber and co-workers believed that the formation of NiPt alloy could lower d-band of Pt, resulting in a decline in the adsorption heats of CO and H2 [56]. As aforementioned, Ni-Pt/Al2O3 catalyst may display high performance for the scission of CC bond due to Ni-rich surface. Meanwhile, its alloy degree is the highest among these studied catalysts. Indeed, the Ni-Pt/Al2O3 catalyst exhibited the least deactivation degree, in agreement with TGA result (in terms of amount of coking and type of coking). In addition, the Pt-Ni/Al2O3 catalyst, as our above inference, may display high performance in dehydrogenation owing to the enriched Pt surface. Investigations that the consequence of coking, composed of amorphous and filamentous coking with olefins through dehydrogenation being the main precursors, had greater impact on deactivation have been reported [53,57]. In combination with the TGA and DTG results, this may explain why Pt-Ni/Al2O3 catalyst displayed more serious deactivation than other catalysts. Therefore, these disparities in amounts of coking and type of coking for these studied spent catalysts are explained by surface properties and alloy degree.

The structure of carbonaceous species on spent catalysts is investigated by Raman technology, described in Fig. 15. The first peak is around at 1350 cm−1, which is associated with the disordered carbon species, for example defective carbon. The second peak centered at ~ 1590 cm−1, corresponding to ordered structure carbon [50]. It has been reported that the value of ID/IG (D band and G band ratio) was used to explain the graphitization degree of carbon deposition [58]. Generally, lower ID/IG ratio means higher graphitization degree of carbonaceous species. As shown in Fig. 15, the ID/IG ratios of these spent catalysts followed the trend of Pt-Ni/Al2O3 < NiPt/Al2O3 ~ Ni-Pt/Al2O3, suggesting that the coke deposited on NiPt/Al2O3 and Ni-Pt/Al2O3 is more disordered, while the counter parts on Pt-Ni/Al2O3 was more ordered. These Raman results are in line with the DTG results.

SEM analysis of spent catalysts (spent catalysts of reaction shown in Fig. 7) are exhibited in Fig. 16. For these spent catalysts, filamentous carbon species are observed, which is consistent with the above TG results.

Different surface structures of NiPt/Al2O3 bimetallic catalysts prepared by tailing Pt locations were investigated for n-dodecane, a sort of model compound of liquid hydrocarbon fuels, steam reforming process. Several results could be drawn from these results;
1.
The performance of these different surface structures NiPt bimetallic catalysts was as followed: Ni-Pt/Al2O3 (Pt-inner) > NiPt/Al2O3 (Pt-outer & inner) > Pt-Ni/Al2O3 (Pt-outer). Characterization analysis indicated that Ni-Pt/Al2O3 catalyst owned Ni-enriched surface, high percentage of Nix+ species and NiPt alloy degree, which synergistically facilitated the CHx group formation, H2O activation and CHx group oxidation, thus enhancing activity.
2.
Even through these different surface structures of NiPt bimetallic catalysts exhibited deactivation due to coking, the deactivation degree was different. Less carbon was formed over Ni-Pt/Al2O3, mainly as filamentous coke/disordered carbon, while serious coking was observed on Pt-Ni/Al2O3 catalyst, ascribed to filamentous coke and graphitic carbon/ordered carbon. The disparities in amounts of carbon and type of coking were associated to the surface structure leading to different reactions in this steam reforming reaction.
